item.title: Microsoft cuts 20GB Xbox 360 to $299.99, launches 60GB model
item.description: Microsoft has announced a price drop for the 20GB Xbox 360, bringing the unit to within spitting distance of the Wii at $299.99. The company also introduced a new 60GB SKU for the 20GB's former cost of $349.99.

item.title: Friend Somehow Bad At Hanging Out
item.description: According to local resident Jay Reagor, his longtime friend Geoff Scovell, 25, is somehow not good at hanging out, the low-pressure recreational pastime in which skill and ability are generally not considered to be factors.

item.title: Jackass Reports on iPhone Line, Gets Called Jackass
Microsoft confirms: Xbox 360 60GB for $349, 20GB now at $299
item.description: Microsoft has confirmed that the 20GB Xbox 360 console has received a $50 price cut to $299, and taking its place in the $349 tier is a new 60GB console and arriving early August. The Xbox 360 Arcade (i.e. no HDD) will continue to sell for $280 and the Elite (120GB) model will sell for $449.

item.title: Smoking is 'good for your memory and concentration'
item.description: Smoking can help boost memory and concentration, say scientists. The discovery offers hope of a nicotine pill that mimics these effects to treat Alzheimer's disease.

item.title: Haulin’ asteroid in Iowa [PIC]
item.description: So I’m out on my bike and I see a UHaul van parked on the road. I like the artwork they put on the sides of the vans; it’s always about some attraction from a specific state. In this case, the state was Iowa, and I was pretty surprised to see this picture...

item.title: Study: An American Life Is Worth Less Today
item.description: It's not just the American $ that's losing value. A government agency has decided that an American life isn't worth what it used to be.The "value of a statistical life" is $6.9 M in today's dollars, a drop of nearly $1M from just five years ago.Though it may seem like a harmless bureaucratic recalculation, devaluation has real consequences.

item.title: How Much Fluid Do We Really Need?
item.description: Too much fluid and we’re waterlogged. Too little and we dry out. The facts are that your body is great at telling you when there’s a fluid-balance blip. Need a drink? It’ll tell you by concentrating your pee and making you thirsty...we’ve survived an awfully long time without having to carry water bottles around like mini life support machines.

item.title: The Supercomputers of Oak Ridge National Lab
item.description: "When you buy a computer this large," Messer said, "You get to pick the color."

item.title: Bionic Bra to Harness the Energy of Bouncing Breasts
item.description: Looking for a better way to charge her iPod on the go, Adrienne So had an idea – could she invent a bionic bra to harness the energy of her bouncing breasts?

item.title: Ancient bones may lead to TB cure
item.description: Archaeologists and medical researchers are joining forces to examine human remains from Jericho in a real-life version of 'Bonekickers'

item.title: What We Say Without Words
item.description: Former FBI agent Joe Navarro describes how our torsos, hands, feet and legs frequently communicate emotions that are not put into words.

item.title: Don’t Sit Close To Computer Screen Or Else You Go Blind
item.description: Eyestrain is a common—and occasionally debilitating—effect of staring at screens

item.title: Will Our Future Brains Be Smaller?
item.description: The speed at which we react to threatening situations can have life or death implications. In the more primitive past, it could have meant escaping a wild animal; today it might mean swerving to avoid a head-on car crash.

item.title: The Greatest Sports Teams Of All Time
item.description: From the '78 Steelers to the '98 Yankees. There was a lot of talk about the 2007 New England Patriots being the best team ever. But after a 17-14 loss to the New York Giants in Super Bowl XLII, the Pats look like just another team that couldn't win the big one.

item.title: Democratic presidencies aren't always bad for stocks
item.description: "The answers provided by almost everyone of whom I ask this question are almost unanimous: The stock market does better under Republican presidents... They're wrong. "

item.title: IGN: Pre-E3 2008 Prince of Persia Preview
item.description: Forget the Prince of Persia you once knew. The new Prince of Persia, built on the Assassin's Creed Anvil engine, is set in a dynamic, open world. The traps you encounter in an area in hour one will be completely different from the ones you come across in hour six. The world continually changes based on the choices you make, bringing replayability .

item.title: How Fallout Could Affect Main Street
item.description: A good look at whether it's worth your while to buy - or sell - a home right now...

item.title: Pulling a Wozniak: App Store Developers "Cutting Line"
item.description: A few Apple App Store developers have apparently taken a page from the line cutting Steve Wozniak today, and are using a loop hole in the service's naming conventions to shoot their apps to the top of the list

item.title: A Drug Sting Gone Bad Because of a Milkshake
item.description: Undercover police officers stormed a McDonald's restaurant and ordered diners and employees to the ground as they tried to catch a suspected cocaine dealer, but things didn't quite go a planned.

item.title: Secret Cave May Solve Mystery of Ancient Civilization
item.description: Archaeologists are to open a long-sealed cave under a Mexican pyramid in the hope that it will unlock the mystery of one of ancient civilisation's greatest cities. Teotihuacan was once the biggest city in the Americas and possibly the world. However, experts have never been able to say with certainty who built it and why it was suddenly abandoned.

item.title: The Batman Movie You Didn’t Know About
item.description: Batman (1943) As a rule, my original concept for Old Ass Movies was to spotlight films that were made before 1960. It’s fairly arbitrary - like most things around here - but I wanted to stick to it. So, when we were gearing up for The Dark Knight, and often-dictator-like Editor Neil Miller wanted me to do this feature on the camp-tastic 1966 versio

item.title: Where To Find The Sexiest Girls In The World (Outside US)
item.description: Rarely do travel guides step up to the question every traveler, male and female alike, cannot help but consider when exploring new terrain: are the locals hot?

item.title: NSFW: Choke Red Band Movie Trailer
item.description: Fox Searchlight has released a new trailer for Clark Gregg’s adaptation of Chuck Palahniuk’s Choke, and it’s Red Band! That’s right, completely uncensored, vulgar, nudity, overall - totally Not Safe For Work. That said, this is a much funnier, more accurate representation of the actual film than the previous trailer.

item.title: The First Negative Review of The Dark Knight
item.description: Everyone I’ve talked to who has seen the film thinks its nothing short of brilliant. But it was bound to happen eventually, the first negative review of The Dark Knight has hit the web.

item.title: Schwarzenegger Slams Bush for Not Believing Global Warming
item.description: In an interview this morning with ABC’s George Stephanopoulos, Schwarzenegger laments that the Bush administration “did not believe in global warming.” He adds that even if officials had done something on Friday, he would have thought it “bogus anyway…because you don’t really have an effect by doing something six months before you leave office“

item.title: Drunk History 3 w/ Danny McBride
item.description: Watch the gripping tale of Oney Judge, George & Martha Washington's favorite slave. Thanks, Derek Waters. Keep these coming!

item.title: Welcome to the 2008 Beijing Olympics
item.description: This song sent chills up my spine, mostly because Jackie Chan is such a badass singer!

item.title: What Happens When Human Rights Are Given to Nonhumans?
item.description: Spain’s recent vote to give limited human rights to Great Apes is a great start at breaking down the species barriers, under which humans are regarded as godlike and the rest of the animal kingdom are treated like dirt. But some are aghast. Catholic bishops attacked the vote as undermining a divine will that placed humans above animals.

item.title: Geothermal Energy Will Help Power Anaheim, CA within 1 year
item.description: After six years of research, Raser Technologies will deliver geothermal energy to the city of Anaheim, California. The geothermal generator, which is located in Beaver County, Utah, will produce 10 megawatts of energy (enough to power 9,000 homes). It should be completed in about 12 months.

item.title: Dear Iran: We have Photoshop, too!
item.description: Several images, all 100% as genuine as the Iranian test launch photos.

item.title: How to be a Internet Cafe Ninja
Cheney Thinks Public Health Threats = Not Our Business?!
item.description: new statements by Jason Barnett, the former associate deputy administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency have revealed that Vice President Cheney’s office sought to delete testimony by the CDC in congressional hearings last fall which proves the negative health consequences for human beings as a result of climate change.

item.title: Apple Customers Insulted by Reporter and they Strike Back
item.description: He asks iPhone customers waiting in line whether or not they have ever seen a naked woman. One guy waiting in line puts him in his place.

item.title: Opinion: How Microsoft Can Turn The Negative Vista PR Tide
item.description: Things have been awfully tough for Microsoft over the past year. Aside from all of its woes with Yahoo and Jerry Yang, the company has faced a PR nightmare on the Vista front.

item.title: Huge Towering Bag of Vaporized Marijuana
item.description: This bag looks like it is well over 6 feet tall and was hooked up to a Volcano vaporizer for minimal health risk and maximum good times.

item.title: Hong Kong on a Sunny Day: An Awesome Panoramic View [PIC]
item.description: A great panoramic shot of Hong Kong on a sunny day.

item.title: XKCD Things Fall Apart
item.description: Mala

item.title: Video Game Characters Are Now Smarter and Less Predictable
item.description: Video games used to come preprogrammed with canned movements that expert players eventually could anticipate and figure out. But recent advancements in video game design - and new game consoles with dazzling computing power - have endowed computer-controlled characters with a sense of self-preservation and unpredictability not seen even a year ago.

item.title: Life... According to Google
